fields.description:
{color:red}This bug report is opened to have reference to the Support Tools Plugin bug at [https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/STP-354].{color}

*Problem Statement*

Though our [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Database+Setup+For+MySQL#DatabaseSetupForMySQL-Step3.ConfigureMySQLServer] states that the innodb_log_file_size should be 2G and higher, this causes Health Check to throw a Problem warning and the following error. This occurs when the size is set to 2G or 2048MB.

h4.Steps to Reproduce
* Modify the my.cnf file, adding (if it doesn't already exist) {{innodb_log_file_size=2G}} or {{innodb_log_file_size=2048M}}
* Restart MySQL
* Navigate to {{Confluence Admin > Atlassian Support Tools > Health Check}}

h5. Expected result
The problem message should be thrown when the innodb_log_file_size is set to *lower* than 2G, according to our documentation.

h5. Actual result
The following error is shown:
{quote}Result
Exception during check invocation: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLDataException: '2.147483648E9' in column '2' is outside valid range for the datatype INTEGER.{quote}

h4. Workaround
The first recommendation would be to ignore the error message and set it to the recommended value.

To simply avoid the error message, you can lower the size to 2047MB and the error is no longer shown, however you are technically then using a lower than recommended size.

h5. Note
This is likely due to the {{INTEGER}} data type in MySQL, which allows the max value of {{2147483647}}: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.6/en/integer-types.html. Any higher value will trigger this error.
fields.summary: Health Check shows "Problem" if innodb_log_file_size is set to 2G or larger for MySQL 5.6

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-37593].
  {panel}

h3. Idea
I think the way [Stack Exchange|http://stackexchange.com/] is handling its user comments is the best way from a user experience perspective. What Stack Exchange provides (and I am pretty sure every developer on this planet knows this) is a two-level comment functionality with a main comment on level 1 and any amount of sub comments to the given main comment on level 2. Level 0 is the question.

h3. New Confluence feature
In Confluence, Level 0 is the Confluence page or blog post. Level 1 should be the main comment, level 1 the sub comments.
In addition, each confluence user should be able to sort the main comments by date decending or ascending. In this context please refer to [CONF-2587|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-2587]. The sorting should have no effect on the sub comments.

*For ascending sort order.*
>PAGE OR BLOG POST
>> Main comment 1
>>> Sub comment 1.1
>>> Sub comment 1.2
>>> ...
>> Main comment 2
>>> Sub comment 2.1
>>> Sub comment 2.2
>>> ...
...

*For descending sort order.*
>PAGE OR BLOG POST
>> Main comment 2
>>> Sub comment 2.1
>>> Sub comment 2.2
>>> ...
>> Main comment 1
>>> Sub comment 1.1
>>> Sub comment 1.2
>>> ...
...
fields.summary: Two level comment system instead of (or in addition to) threaded comments

{code}[atlassian.util.profiling.UtilTimerStack] log [1455ms] - /confluence/display/SAN/Simple+Docx{code}

fields.description:
The Attachment Removed event is currently fired when an an attachment is removed from a page.  In the 5.8.1-beta2 it looks like this event is fired when the attachment is purged from the trash.

This represents a change in behaviour for the event.  For plugins that listen to this event this will be difficult to work around because the new Attachment Trashed event is a 5.8 event only.

Suggested Fix:
* Make AttachmentRemoved event fired at same time as the new AttachmentTrashed event.
* Add a new AttachmentPurged Event.
* Deprecate the existing AttachmentRemoved event
fields.summary: Behaviour of attachment removed event changed in Confluence 5.8

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Users have the ability to view a list of all blog posts, even from spaces in which they don't have permission to access.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Confluence 5.7.x
# Create two spaces
** Space A 
** Space B (remove all permissions for confluence-users)
# Create a blog post in Space A
# Create a blog post in Space B
# Create and login as a new regular user
# Goto the blog post in Space A
# Click the Month in the page breadcrumbs

h3. Expected Results
The user should only see the the blog post from Space A listed

h3. Actual Results
The user will see both blog posts listed.

h3. Notes
# If the user attempts to view the blog post from Space B, it will give a Page Not Found message as expected
# This behavior can also be achieved by going directly to http://<confluencehost>/display/<spacekey>/2015/05 (or any combination of year and day)
# This behavior worked as expected in Confluence 5.6.x
fields.summary: Space permissions ignored in list of blog posts by date

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-37541].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, if a user wants to be able to include a page from a space (Space A) with restrictions to a space (Space B) that doesn't have the same restrictions, only those users with permissions to Space A will see the content, all other users will see a message that the macro is unable to render.

h3. Suggested Solution
Knowing that too drastic of a change could cause security issues, maybe add the ability for a space or site admin to waive permission checks on a case by case basis in the macro itself (a toggle or checkbox should do the trick). 

h3. Workaround 
Copy the page into a space that has fewer restrictions, and then include that page.
fields.summary: Add the ability to waive permissions checks for the include page macro

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-37523].
  {panel}

Basic example AD setup is as follows:

{noformat}
Groups
 `- Security Groups
    `- Confluence
       `- Confluence Users
       `- Confluence ReadOnly Users
       `- Confluence Space1 Users
 `- Department Groups
    `- Department1
    `- Department2
{noformat}

We've set up the AD Base DN to the AD base, then set Additional Group DN to "OU=Confluence,OU=Groups".

Confluence now sees the 3 Confluence related groups only, without dumping all hundreds of groups we have in AD into the Confluence system, this works very well.

However, I've added Department1 and Department2 into the various Confluence groups, and they're not being recursed into, I assume because they are outside the Additional Group DN. This means no users are added into their groups, even though AD-wise, they are in there.

This is not a unique setup, and I've found a few other cases using Google running into the same issues.

It would be beneficial to just recurse through all groups given, regardless of Additional Group DN - or at least have an option to do so.
fields.summary: Active Directory/LDAP groups do not recurse outside group base

fields.description:
It appears that $generalUtil base64Encode implements the url-safe (-) alphabet (63rd character) that is supposed to be more safe when put into URLs as (+) may mean space?

https://code.google.com/p/stringencoders/wiki/WebSafeBase64

RFC 3548 & RFC 4648 - 

There is recommendation:

This encoding may be referred to as "base64url".  This encoding
   should not be regarded as the same as the "base64" encoding and
   should not be referred to as only "base64".  Unless clarified
   otherwise, "base64" refers to the base 64 in the previous section.

Some decoders seem to be assuming (+) as 63rd character in their alphabets, especially if older versions of libraries are used (ahem that so handy system perl MIME::Base64)

Perhaps clarify in the doc or even add a flag (which alphabet to use) so other dinosaurs like me don't get confused over this :) Thanks

I managed to work/around by using bytes[] = getBytes() and then turning it into base64 with $textUtil.encodeBytes() - that seems to be using the "original" alphabet.

Comment below shows the example of the difference.

Cheers
fields.summary: User Macros $generalUtil.base64Encode assumes url safe alphabet

fields.description:
h3. Problem summary
Since updating to Confluence 5.7.1, tables no longer respect image sizes. Images appear to be the correct size in edit mode, but when saved are drastically shrunk. This is affecting pages that had been previously created/saved and looked normal before the upgrade and new pages. Screenshots are attached. Look specifically at the register buttons. In preview mode those are the actual sizes of the images, and when saved, they look like blue dashes.

The cause for this is because the images do not have a fixed size set. When clicking on the image, the image toolbar shows the size as "Original", implying that the original size of the image will be what is displayed on the page after it is saved. However, the actual behavior is that the image in view mode will be influenced based on the other elements on the page when rendered in View mode, which is especially apparent in a table that is shared with another column that has a lot of text (see screenshots for examples).

h3. Steps to reproduce
# In Confluence 5.7.1, create a page with a two-column table
# In the first column, drag-and-drop an image that is smaller than 250px in height (e.g. [^shark.jpg], 200px in height)
# In the second column, insert an LoremIpsum macro
# Save the page

h3. Expected behavior
The image is displayed at the same size as shown in the editor, as implied by "Original" image size setting

h3. Actual behavior
The image shrinks in size depending on the other elements in the page

h3. Other notes
* This behavior affects images that are 249px or less in height.
* This behavior does not affect uploaded images that are 250px or greater in size, as Confluence automatically assigns a pre-set "medium" size to these images.
* However, if images 250px or greater are manually set to use the "Original" size (i.e. overriding the Confluence default assigned size), then these images will lose their fixed display size, and will be affected.
* This behavior is observed in Chrome and Safari, but not Firefox. Firefox will display the images true to their original size.

h3. Workaround 1 (simple)
The workaround to get around this problem is to assign a fixed size manually to the small images.
# Click on the images once they are uploaded
# Select one of the pre-set sizes (small, medium, or large) as you see fit. These pre-set sizes map to the following pixel counts, in image _width_:
{code}
        sizes = {
            small: 100,
            medium: 300,
            large: 500
        };
{code}
# Save the page, and the image should be fixed to whatever size you have configured, and will not change despite the rest of the page.

h3. Workaround 2 (complex)
Alternatively, if one of these pre-set sizes don't work for you, you can also set an explicit size by inputting a px size using the leftmost field in the image toolbar. By default this field will show the full width of the image, in pixels. The tricky part about this is that unless you enter a different value that what is there, it won't store the value. You must set this value to something else, then back to the original value, as detailed below.
# Click on the images once they are uploaded
# Take note of the pixel value in the leftmost box, and then set it to something else. Press enter. The option "Original" should now be un-highlighted
# Set the text box back to the original pixel value, and press enter again.
# Save the page, and the image should be fixed to whatever size you have configured, and will not change despite the rest of the page.
fields.summary: Images are resized in tables if image size is set to "Original"

Insert a table

add some table headers in 'Paragraph' format

Save the page.

Edit the page

select one header of the table.

Click on the selection for the header types and try to set 'Header3'

Firefox looses the focus after 'Header2' so it's not possible to click.

As a bypass the user can select using the cursor keys and hit 'Enter', but it should work

also mouse driven?

Using Chrome the error does not appear!

Is there a fix in sight for that?
fields.summary: Firefox loses focus on selecting header type

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-37461].
  {panel}

The upgrade procedure for Confluence datacenter:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Upgrading+Confluence+Data+Center
specifies that you must stop all nodes in a cluster before upgrading confluence.

For enterprises where uptime on Confluence is really important, it would be really valuable if we could carry out live rolling upgrades, where we can take a single node down, upgrade it, bring it up and then upgrade the remaining nodes one by one.

I can understand that if the upgrade requires significant database schema changes that it might be harder to implement, but for minor version upgrades i would have thought this would be possible.
fields.summary: Allow rolling upgrade in Confluence Datacenter
